Dear Ms. Hinton:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 6/18/2025. An Exit conference was held with yout agency on 6/18/2025 . Due to the
violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and make
a licensing recommendation to the department at least
15 calendar days before the expiration date of the
foster home license.
One of two closed foster home records reviewed showed the agency’s
recommendation to the department for voluntary license closure of the foster
home occurred over two months after the foster home’s 3/28/2025 license
expiration date.
Repeat Violation Established.
Interim 2024, CAP approved 9/26/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12325 License recommendation.
(3) Except for an original license, an agency shall
recommend to the department the issuance of a
regular license or the continuation of an active license
only when all rules are in compliance or both of the
following conditions exist:

(b) A written corrective action plan has been
developed. The plan must comply with all of the
following requirements:
(iii) Be signed and dated by the foster parent and the
agency.
One of two open foster home records reviewed showed the foster home had a
special evaluation that required a corrective action plan; and the corrective action
plan on file was not signed by the agency or foster parents.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• R400.12325(3)(b)(ii) License recommendation: The agency was
apprised it shall consistently ensure for completion of the foster home’s
corrective action plan as required by the rule. If no date is listed, the date
developed with the foster home shall serve as that date. Additionally,
CWLM issues preventing corrective action plan development or print out
shall be timely worked through with the helpdesk.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• R400.12308(1) Application submission: The agency was advised
ensuring for consistent and regular social work contact entries in CWLM
on the status of the license being completed, (i.e. no monthly gaps) may
aid it in showing it is acting on a completed and signed application.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period. That corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2024 Interim
inspection where it received 9 rule violations. During this 2025 Renewal
inspection the agency received 2 rule violations,1 of which was a repeat violation
from 2024. The agency’s corrective action plan compliance around this 1 rule
violation is as follows: the number of individual cases cited remained the same, in
that 1 of 2 records was cited this year compared to 1 of 3 in 2024.

A review of the agency’s 2024 Interim corrective action plan showed it completed
and or implemented all aspects of the corrective action plan. Notwithstanding that,
it is worth noting that the agency is still learning CWLM and has experienced some
difficulties around report generation and documentation. The agency admitted this
is an area it is continuing to work on.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a chief administrator’s (CA) report signed and dated
6/9/2025. The CA reported the citations from 2024 and how action steps
implement to come into compliance. The reported indicated the corrective action
plan enabled the agency to implement strategies that will have long term positive
impacts for its compliance to the personnel records rule, as well as the agency’s
hiring practices for new staff. The agency reported its retention of staff,
supervisory overall support for the program, and increases in recruitment and in
the budget for recruitment are program strengths. An area of growth reported
was consistency in maintaining treatment foster homes and increasing the
licensing of treatment foster homes.
During the entrance conference, the agency reported it has made some gains
toward licensing more foster homes. They reported their recruitment activities
have gone from 3 community outreaches a month, one of which included a
presentation on a Podcast show. The agency attributed these community
outreaches to having 6 enrolled foster homes. The licensing supervisor reported
they are shooting for licensing 1- 3 foster homes per year.
The chief administrator and licensing supervisor reported they are continuing to
work toward full compliance with the rules. They were also pleased with the fact
the number of violations the agency received this year decreased from the prior
year.
Financial Overview
The agency provided a 2025 annual budget, and independent financial audit dated
for 9/30/2024. A review of these documents did not show indications of any
notable areas of concern.
Staff Interviews
In addition to a discussion with the chief administrator and licensing supervisor, I
interviewed the licensing worker. No concerns were reported. Strengths for the
agency were reported as the program’s tight-knit team; the wall of support from
the team and the administration; and the extra pay that’s offered. Area for growth
was cited as a need for the administration to reach out and do more to educate
other components of The Guidance Center about the treatment foster care
program and what the program does and offers.

Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of this satellite office did not reveal any safety concerns. There
appears to be sufficient equipment for staff; and licensing files were securely
stored.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
This agency is not contracted with the Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services to provide foster care placement or certification services; therefore, this is
not applicable.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
